bibl.title: Letter from A.S. Pinto to Philip Showalter Hench, December 22, 1941

div1.p: Pinto writes to Hench that he visited Truby, and thinks his work is good, but that he has slipped over time. He hopes that Truby completes his article soon.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. Pinto to Philip Showalter Hench, December 22, 1941
div1.opener:
CITY OF OMAHA
HEALTH DEPARTMENT
OMAHA, NEB.
----
A. S. PINTO, M. D.
HEALTH COMMISSIONER
Dec. 22, 1941 Omaha, Nebr.
A. GREENBERG, M. D.
DEPUTY HEALTH COMMISSIONER
J. C. FOLLMAN, M. D.
EMERGENCY PHYSICIAN
F. E. COLIEN, PH. D.
DIRECTOR LABORATORIES
C. B. KINNISON
ASSISTANT
Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of the 22nd ult. at hand, and I have read and re-read your
letter as well as the very excellent article you have had printed in Hygeia.
The yellow fever matter has come up more forceably lately and I have corres-
ponded quite a little with Truby. As you know he is writing a personal history
of it. I have also had several communications from Kean.

I was in San Francisco in early November and called on Truby whom I had
not seen since 1906 in Omaha, and while his work is good I found that he had
slipped very markedly since my associations with him years ago. Of course, I
understand a man cannot retain his full faculties to the end of life, however,
I hope Truby will complete his article shortly.

Your interest in this matter is very commendable and you have certainly
gone to a great deal of work in research and visitation with the different ones
who were connected in any way with the experiment. You say that you will per-
haps go through Omaha later on this winter, so if you do, I certainly insist
that you come to see me and we can talk over this matter from beginning to end.
Any time will suit me so make your plans accordingly.

I was so disgusted with some of the last statements in Truby's notes as
some things John Kissinger said about Dean being bitten by the mosquitoe. In
the first place, Kissinger never knew Dean, nor never talked to him until after
I left there in the fall of 1900. I cannot understand after a lapse of so many
years why a man can try to make capital out of whole cloth which has been done
a good many times in this experiment. I assure you of my interest and willing-
ness to give you a clear picture of what I saw. The picture Yellow Jack has
too many discrepancies.

Feel free to bring along any questions or if you prefer send them to me
by mail and I will be glad to answer them with any information that I may have.

Thanking you for your interest in this matter and assuring you of my heart-
felt cooperation, I remain,
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Dr. A.S. Pinto asp/kh
